title: SQL Injection in Login Form
description: A critical SQL injection vulnerability was discovered in the application's login form. The username field is vulnerable to SQL injection attacks, allowing attackers to bypass authentication and potentially extract sensitive data from the database. The vulnerability is caused by improper input validation and direct concatenation of user input into SQL queries.

title: Training Data from URL: https://medium.com/ctf-writeups/hack-the-box-jerry-write-up-6f045601315f
description: The write-up details the exploitation of the 'Jerry' box on Hack The Box, which runs on Windows with the IP 10.10.10.95 and Apache Tomcat on port 8080. The initial step involved using default credentials ('tomcat' and 's3cret') to access the Manager App, which allows for the upload of a WAR file. An authenticated RCE was achieved using the Metasploit module `multi/http/tomcat_mgr_upload`, leading to immediate system access. The author found both flags needed for submission in a directory on the Administrator's desktop. The overall difficulty of the box is rated as "Piece of cake," making it an accessible challenge for beginners.

title: Training Data from URL: https://medium.com/ctf-writeups/hack-the-box-jerry-write-up-6f045601315f
description: The write-up details the exploitation of the 'Jerry' box on Hack The Box, which runs on Windows with an IP of 10.10.10.95. The initial step involved using Nmap to identify that Apache Tomcat was running on port 8080. The author discovered default login credentials for the Tomcat Manager App, which allowed them to upload a WAR file—an exploit using the Metasploit module `multi/http/tomcat_mgr_upload`. This led to an authenticated remote code execution (RCE) without needing privilege escalation, as the Apache service ran as root. Upon gaining shell access, the author quickly found the necessary flags for submission, highlighting the box's relative ease for beginners.
